title: George N. Morgan
text:
George Nelson Morgan (September 7, 1825 – July 24, 1866) was a <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> officer in the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>.
Biography.
George N. Morgan was born in <a href="Massena%2C%20New%20York">Massena, New York</a>, September 7, 1825. He moved to <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> and was a foundry and machine shop operator.
Morgan joined the <a href="1st%20Minnesota%20Volunteer%20Infantry">1st Minnesota Volunteer Infantry</a> and was appointed <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a>, May 29, 1861, <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a>, October 23, 1861, <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>, October 2, 1862, and <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a>, November 14, 1862. He commanded the regiment at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Fredericksburg">Battle of Fredericksburg</a>. He had temporary command of a brigade in the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Potomac">Army of the Potomac</a>, beginning December 14, 1862.
Because of <a href="tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a>, he resigned, May 4, 1863, but was recovered sufficiently to be appointed major of the 2nd Regiment, <a href="Veteran%20Reserve%20Corps">Veteran Reserve Corps</a>, May 26, 1863 and colonel, September 25, 1863. He commanded <a href="Fort%20Snelling%2C%20Minnesota">Fort Snelling, Minnesota</a>, a training facility.
On January 13, 1866, <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Andrew%20Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> nominated Morgan for appointment to the grade of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers, to rank from March 13, 1865, and the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> confirmed the appointment on March 12, 1866. Morgan was mustered out of the volunteers on June 30, 1866.
Morgan's tuberculosis worsened and he died at <a href="Minneapolis%2C%20Minnesota">Minneapolis, Minnesota</a>, July 24, 1866. He was buried at <a href="Lakewood%20Cemetery">Lakewood Cemetery</a>, Minneapolis.
His son, <a href="George%20H.%20Morgan">George H. Morgan</a>, later became a <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> officer, and was awarded the <a href="Medal%20of%20Honor">Medal of Honor</a>.
Namesake.
Morgan Avenue in <a href="Minneapolis">Minneapolis</a> is named for George N. Morgan.
